mainDescriptionHRV:
Većina danas vidljivih ostataka prapovijesnih struktura na području Velebita potječe iz brončanoga i željeznoga doba, dakle od oko 2500. godine pa do I. stoljeća prije Krista. Brončano doba karakterizira postupno raslojavanje društva čija elita temelji svoju moć na proizvodnji i razmjeni predmeta od kovina i drugih rijetkih dobara. Društveni dodiri i mreže razmjene u tim razdobljima sve čvršće povezuju obje strane Velebita; dok je primorska padina Velebita pripadala pomorski usmjerenim Liburnima, kontinentalnu stranu planine nastanjuju Japodi.

U takvim okolnostima podižu se u podnožju Velebita prve monumentalne građevine – gradine i gomile. Gradine su pretpovijesne utvrde izgrađene na uzvisinama i istaknutim strateškim položajima. Najčešće su podignute na krševitim glavicama i grebenima, a bile su utvrđene bedemima građenima u tehnici suhozida od krupnoga neobrađenog kamenja. Većina gradina nanizana je duž nižega dijela primorske padine Velebita, no ima ih i na većim visinama. Iako su mnogi suhozidni bedemi gradina s vremenom srušeni i rasuti niz padine, još uvijek se mjestimice mogu uočiti, a neki su visoki i po nekoliko metara.
Gradine su imale različite namjene: neke su služile kao zaklon stanovnicima obližnjih zaselaka u slučaju opasnosti, neke su štitile značajnije prostore plodnih polja ili pašnjaka te su ujedno nadzirale pastirske i trgovačke puteve koji su vodili u Velebit, preko njega i u Liku, a one podignute nad Velebitskim kanalom vjerojatno su služile kao stražarnice za nadziranje plovidbe.
Oko gradina obično se nalaze gomile: grobovi lokalnih moćnika koji su za brončanoga i željeznoga doba gospodarili Velebitom. Mnogi od njih pokopani su pod velikim, okruglim gomilama od nabacanog kamenja ispod kojih se nalaze grobnice od kamenih ploča.
Pojedine gomile ističu se svojim položajem na ključnim mjestima unutar krajolika, kao što su važni prijevoji i sjecišta puteva. Osim što su to jasno vidljivi spomenici podignuti istaknutim članovima prapovijesnih zajednica, gomile su svojim prisustvom jasno svjedočile o trajnom pripadanju nekog prostora određenoj lokalnoj zajednici. U kasnijim stoljećima gomile su često bile na meti pljačkaša, a kamenje s njih odnošeno je za gradnju suhozidâ ili upotrebljavano kao građevinski materijal. Gomile su ugrožene i u današnje vrijeme kada nestaju pod pritiskom izgradnje prometnica i širenja naselja.
mainDescriptionENG:
Most of the visible remains of prehistoric structures in the Velebit area today date back to the Bronze and Iron Ages, that is, from about 2500 to the first century BC. The Bronze Age is characterized by the gradual stratification of a society whose elite bases its power on the production and exchange of objects made of metals and other rare goods. Social touches and exchange networks in these periods increasingly connect both sides of Velebit; while the coastal slope of Velebit belonged to the maritimely oriented Liburnians, the continental side of the mountain is inhabited by Japodi.

In such circumstances, they are erected at the foot of Velebit of the first monumental building – hill forts and piles. Forts are prehistoric fortifications built on elevations and prominent strategic positions. Most often they were erected on karst heads and ridges, and were fortified by ramparts built in the technique of drywall from large untreated stones. Most of the hill forts are strung along the lower part of the coastal slope of Velebit, but there are also at higher altitudes. Although many drywall ramparts of hill forts have been demolished and scattered down the slopes over time, they can still be spotted in places, and some are several meters high. The hill forts had different purposes: some served as shelter for residents of nearby hamlets in case of danger, some protected significant areas of fertile fields or pastures, and also supervised shepherd and trade routes leading to Velebit, through it and in Lika, and those erected over the Velebit Channel probably served as watchtowers for monitoring navigation.
Around the hill forts there are usually piles: the graves of local powerful people who ruled Velebit during the Bronze and Iron Ages. Many of them are buried under large, round piles of nagged stones under which there are tombs of stone slabs. Some crowds stand out for their location in key places within the landscape, such as important passes and intersections of roads. In addition to being clearly visible monuments erected to prominent members of prehistoric communities, the crowds clearly testified with their presence to the permanent belonging of a space to a particular local community. In later centuries, crowds were often targeted by looters, and stones from them were carried away for the construction of drywalls or used as building materials. Crowds are threatened even nowadays when they disappear under the pressure of building roads and expanding settlements.
